name: maintenance, container ship | maintenance, container ship | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21780/documentation

The dataset represents the maintenance of one container ship with a load capacity (DWT) of 43,000 tonnes.;It is assumed that the ship undergoes two full maintenance regimes (stripping and repainting of all surfaces) and four smaller maintenance regimes (stripping and repainting of the hull) during an assumed 25 year lifetime (Demirel et al., 2013 and Hayman et al., N.d.). The dataset includes the quantity of paint used, emissions of volatiles, and emissions of paint to land and water from stripping and application. The dataset also includes the material and energy required for sandblasting, and emissions of particulates. A 10% replacement of steel over the ship's lifetime is assumed from Johnson & Fet (1998).;References: ;Demirel, Y., Khorasanchi, M., Turan, O. and Incecik, A. (2013) On the importance of antifouling coatings regarding ship resistance and powering, Low Carbon Shipping Conference, London, UK.;Hayman, B., Dogliani, M., Kvale, I. and Fet, A. (n.d.) Technologies for reduced environmental impact from ships - Ship building, maintenance and dismantling aspects, TRESHIP Thematic Network: Brussels, Belgium;Johnsen, T. and Fet, A. (1998) Screening Life Cycle Assessment of M/V Color Festival, The Research Council of Norway: Oslo, Norway.

Maintenance of ship, starting with receiving/obtaining the material inputs required.

The activity ends with the maintenance of one ship. The dataset includes material consumption (paint, steel and sand), energy consumption (diesel for sandblasting) and emissions from painting (volatiles and paint) and particulates (sandblasting). The dataset does not include the consumption of liquids and oils (e.g. lubricants, refigerants etc.).
category: C:Manufacturing/33:Repair and installation of machinery and equipment/331:Repair of fabricated metal products, machinery and equipment/3315:Repair of transport equipment, except motor vehicles

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Sand blasting is the most common medium of abrasive blastive for commercial ships (OECD, 2009).

flow.name: maintenance, container ship
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/33:Repair and installation of machinery and equipment/331:Repair of fabricated metal products, machinery and equipment/3315:Repair of transport equipment, except motor vehicles

exchanges.description: Steel replacement over lifetime, including estimated wastage percentage. Based on: Ship lightweight mass calculated from IHSF data, Papanikolaou (2014) and Anink & Krikke (2011). 85% of ship mass estimated to be steel ( Jain et al., 2016). 10% replacement of steel during lifetime estimated by Johnson & Fet (1998). Material wastage data estimated by Papanikolaou (2014).

exchanges.description: Paint to land from stripping and repainting. Based on: Ship lightweight mass calculated from IHSF data, Papanikolaou (2014) and Anink & Krikke (2011). Paint usage data estimated by Kameyama et al. (n.d.), Harish & Sunil (2014) and Nicolae et al. (2014). Paint emission data from OECD (2009). It is assumed that the ship undergoes 2 full maintenance regimes (stripping and repainting of all surfaces) and 4 smaller (stripping and repainting of the hull) during its 25 year lifetime (Demirel et al. (2013); Hayman et al. (N.d.)). Unspecified hydrocarbons to land used as a proxy for paint emissions to land.

It is assumed that the ship undergoes 2 full maintenance regimes (stripping and repainting of all surfaces) and 4 smaller (stripping and repainting of the hull) during its 25 year lifetime (Demirel et al. (2013); Hayman et al. (N.d.)).

exchanges.description: Particulates to air during sandblasting. Based on: Ship lightweight mass calculated from IHSF data, Papanikolaou (2014) and Anink & Krikke (2011). Sand usage and loss to air during maintenance estimated by Johnson & Fet (1998). Particulate size distribution from sand blasting from US EPA 1995. It is assumed that the ship undergoes 2 full maintenance regimes (stripping and repainting of all surfaces) and 4 smaller (stripping and repainting of the hull) during its 25 year lifetime (Demirel et al. (2013); Hayman et al. (N.d.)). Sand blasting assumed as abrasive blasting is most common for commercial ships OECD (2009).

exchanges.description: Diesel for sandblasting (compressor) approximated by "diesel burned in building machine, GLO 2001" with 0.0234 kg diesel burnt per MJ produced. Mass of diesel based on: Ship lightweight mass calculated from IHSF data, Papanikolaou (2014) and Anink & Krikke (2011). Diesel usage during sand blasting estimated by Johnson & Fet (1998). It is assumed that the ship undergoes 2 full maintenance regimes (stripping and repainting of all surfaces) and 4 smaller (stripping and repainting of the hull) during its 25 year lifetime (Demirel et al. (2013); Hayman et al. (N.d.)). Sand blasting assumed as abrasive blasting is most common for commercial ships OECD (2009).

exchanges.description: Based on: Ship lightweight mass calculated from IHSF data, Papanikolaou (2014) data and Anink & Krikke (2011) data. Sand usage during maintenance estimated by Johnson & Fet (1998) and the assumption that all sand not lost to the air or water goes to waste. It is assumed that the ship undergoes 2 full maintenance regimes (stripping and repainting of all surfaces) and 4 smaller (stripping and repainting of the hull) during its 25 year lifetime (Demirel et al. (2013); Hayman et al. (N.d.)). Sand blasting assumed as abrasive blasting is most common for commercial ships OECD (2009). Foundry waste sand used as proxy for sandblasting sand waste.

exchanges.description: 10% of sand used in blasting assumed to end up in water (after Johnsen & Fet (1998)). Amount of sand used in blasting based on: Ship lightweight mass calculated from IHSF data, Papanikolaou (2014) and Anink & Krikke (2011). Sand usage and loss to water during maintenance estimated by Johnson & Fet (1998). It is assumed that the ship undergoes 2 full maintenance regimes (stripping and repainting of all surfaces) and 4 smaller (stripping and repainting of the hull) during its 25 year lifetime (Demirel et al. (2013); Hayman et al. (N.d.)). Sand blasting assumed as abrasive blasting is most common for commercial ships OECD (2009). Inorganics solids to water used as a proxy for sand to water emissions.
